name: Hip Hop
description: Emerged primarily on the United States East Coast in African-American communities in the late 1970s; emphasizes rhythmic beat patterns and a type of spoken vocal delivery known as rapping.

sub_genres.name: Abstract Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Uses much more abstract lyricism than what is considered conventional within the genre, typically through use of metaphors, symbolism, and cryptic meanings.

sub_genres.name: Afro Trap
sub_genres.description: Centered mostly in France, features production influenced by modern styles developed in West and Central Africa with Trap-styled vocal flows.

sub_genres.name: Afroswing
sub_genres.description: Emerged in the United Kingdom during the mid-2010s, incorporating influences from Dancehall, Afrobeats, Contemporary R&B, and a variety of West African Music.

sub_genres.name: Arabesque Rap
sub_genres.description: Emerged from Turkey in the late 2000s, based almost exclusively around Arabesk samples and featuring aggressive rap vocals.

sub_genres.name: Bongo Flava
sub_genres.description: Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.

sub_genres.name: Boom Bap
sub_genres.description: Production style identified by an acoustic-sounding drum pattern of a kick drum on the downbeat followed by a cracking snare on the upbeat.

sub_genres.name: Bounce
sub_genres.description: Developed in New Orleans in the early 1990s, initially defined by a slow to midtempo beat with a double-time hi-hat on top.

sub_genres.name: Chipmunk Soul
sub_genres.description: Sped-up vocal samples and slick, soulful production.

sub_genres.name: Chopped and Screwed
sub_genres.description: Remixing technique that consists of skipping effects ("chopping") and dropping the tempo ("screwing").

sub_genres.name: Christian Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Employs lyrics with a pro-Christianity message to profess the performer's faith, often to attract attention from new potential converts.

sub_genres.name: Cloud Rap
sub_genres.description: Emerged in the early 2010s, known for its relaxed, dream-like, and reverb-heavy production style, taking influence from Chillwave, and producers' obscure sample choices.

sub_genres.name: Comedy Rap
sub_genres.description: Primarily intended to be humorous, through the use of comedic lyrics, production, delivery, or other musical aspects.

sub_genres.name: Conscious Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Artists whose lyrics deal with social issues.

sub_genres.name: Country Rap
sub_genres.description: Combines the flow, production-emphasis, and demeanor of Hip Hop with the lyrical content and general approach of Country.

sub_genres.name: Crunk
sub_genres.description: Originating from the southern United States and reliant on drum machines and synthesizer stabs to create an energetic, often dance-oriented sound.

sub_genres.name: Crunkcore
sub_genres.description: Combines rapping, screaming and autotune with synthesizers and Hip Hop beats often influenced by Crunk.

sub_genres.name: Detroit Sound
sub_genres.description: Upbeat 808 percussion; simple, funky mallet instruments, keys, strings, and synth bass; and street-centric, often punched-in rapping.

sub_genres.name: Digicore
sub_genres.description: Developed in the late 2010s and characterized by frantic, bombastic, and glamourous production, usually derived from Trap, that serves to accompany highly melodious, auto-tuned, and hi-pitched vocal performances, often done with breathy voice singing and sing-rapping.

sub_genres.name: Dirty South
sub_genres.description: Originated in the Southern US during the mid-1990s, defined by a bouncy rhythm, fast-tempo snares, 808s, heavy bass, and often rapped in a rhythmic delivery consisting of explicit lyrics.

sub_genres.name: Disco Rap
sub_genres.description: Most prevalent from 1979 to 1982, featuring MCs rapping over popular Disco breaks.

sub_genres.name: Drill
sub_genres.description: Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s; broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms coupled with gang-oriented, street-conscious, and violent lyrics.

sub_genres.name: Drumless
sub_genres.description: Stripped-down production style pioneered in the early 2010s and identified by a lack of drums or minimal, subtle percussion left untouched from the original sample or filtered out.

sub_genres.name: Emo Rap
sub_genres.description: Moody, melancholic production combining atmospheric Cloud Rap, and Trap's typical drum programming, with sampling from Alternative Rock, Midwest Emo, Emo-Pop, and Pop Punk.

sub_genres.name: Experimental Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Incorporates experimental and eccentric elements considered unconventional or unorthodox compared to more traditional hip hop.

sub_genres.name: G-Funk
sub_genres.description: Relaxed and organic sound featuring live instrumentation, use of P-Funk samples, and high-pitched synth lines.

sub_genres.name: Genge
sub_genres.description: Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.

sub_genres.name: Hardcore Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Confrontation and aggression, whether in the lyricism, vocal delivery, hard beats, heavy production, or any combination thereof.

sub_genres.name: Hipco
sub_genres.description: Developed in Liberia, often featuring conscious and political lyrics and influences from local dance styles.

sub_genres.name: Hiplife
sub_genres.description: Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.

sub_genres.name: Houston Sound
sub_genres.description: Features slow to medium tempos, heavy bass, prominent organs and horns, and live instruments such as keyboards, bass guitar and wah-wah pedal.

sub_genres.name: Hyphy
sub_genres.description: Party-focused style with upbeat tempos, heavy bass and prominent synths, all underpinned by a distinctive West Coast-style rhythm, claps on beats 2 and 4, and a strong kick drum on beats 1, 2, and either 3 or 4.

sub_genres.name: Instrumental Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Can take the form of instrumental versions of songs that normally feature rapping, or hip hop originally released and always intended to be instrumental.

sub_genres.name: Jazz Rap
sub_genres.description: Incorporates elements of Jazz through the use of samples or live instrumentation.

sub_genres.name: Jerk
sub_genres.description: Sparse, snare-heavy drum patterns loosely inspired by Jerk Rap, which take major elements from other prominent 2010s and 2020s underground hip hop genres like Plugg.

sub_genres.name: Jersey Club Rap
sub_genres.description: Incorporates Jersey Club's distinct kick-heavy rhythms, which are modified to better suit rapping, featuring less sampling and more atmospheric production than earlier Jersey club.

sub_genres.name: Jigg
sub_genres.description: Club-oriented genre characterized by heavy 808-driven beats, imposing synthesized brasses and an uptempo rhythm.

sub_genres.name: Jook
sub_genres.description: Fast-paced; draws influence from Bounce, Miami Bass, Jersey Club and Dancehall.

sub_genres.name: Latin Rap
sub_genres.description: Primarily done in Spanish; incorporates Hispanic American Music elements into its sound.

sub_genres.name: Lo-Fi Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Relaxed, laid-back form of Hip Hop, typically instrumental and influenced by Jazz Rap and Downtempo.

sub_genres.name: Lowend
sub_genres.description: Rhythms driven by steady eighth-note digital handclaps, rattling bass, fast tempos, upbeat sound, and laid-back flows.

sub_genres.name: Miami Bass
sub_genres.description: Sustained Roland TR-808 kick drums and faster tempos, along with a distinct Electro influence.

sub_genres.name: Mobb Music
sub_genres.description: San Francisco Bay Area production style building on slowed down Funk (often utilizing live elements).

sub_genres.name: Motswako
sub_genres.description: Mainly rapped in a mixture of Setswana and English, incorporating additional languages and local South African and Botswanan influences, particularly Kwaito.

sub_genres.name: Nerdcore Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Themes touch on such nerd mainstays as science, computers, and science fiction.

sub_genres.name: Nervous Music
sub_genres.description: Dark, sinister and menacing sound, heavy sub-basses, simple melodies and slow, sparse and slamming drums.

sub_genres.name: Philly Club Rap
sub_genres.description: Mixes the fast and energetic production of Philly Club with similarly frantic and fast rapping.

sub_genres.name: Political Hip Hop
sub_genres.description: Features explicitly political lyrics and themes.

sub_genres.name: Pop Rap
sub_genres.description: Fuses Hip Hop's rapping and production traits with Pop elements such as melodious vocals and light, catchy tunes.

sub_genres.name: Ratchet
sub_genres.description: Club-oriented style defined by a repeated synth melody and a sparse drum pattern often accompanied by a "hey" chant.

sub_genres.name: Sigilkore
sub_genres.description: Dark and hyperactive production, featuring rapping laced with layers of effects.

sub_genres.name: Snap
sub_genres.description: Sparse production, pounding 808 bass, occasional use of third-beat finger snaps, and simple melodies reminiscent of ringtones.

sub_genres.name: Stoner Rap
sub_genres.description: Heavily features lyrics about cannabis and stoner culture, usually with a laid-back flow and relaxing production.

sub_genres.name: Trap
sub_genres.description: Originated in Atlanta in the early 2000s; distinctive fast hi-hat sound and heavy bass at moderate tempos.

sub_genres.name: Trap shaabi
sub_genres.description: Combining Trap percussion and rhythms with Egyptian Shaabi and especially Mahraganat.

sub_genres.name: Turntablism
sub_genres.description: Manipulating and re-appropriating vinyl records using a turntable and DJ mixer in a Hip Hop context, often featuring constant scratching and beat juggling between two or more recordings into original, distinctive tracks.
